newsitem.title: MAURITIUS: Kabila's Congo to launch reform, review mining law.
newsitem.headline: Kabila's Congo to launch reform, review mining law.

text.p: The new government of the Democratic Republic of the Congo will soon launch economic reforms, including a review of the country's mining and investment rules, Mines Minister Florent Mututulo said on Tuesday.

"A serious reform will be undertaken in the very near future in order to (make) the following more adaptable in the modern investment climate: the investment code, the mining code and the fiscal," Mututulo told delegates at a sub-Saharan Oil and Minerals conference.
He said restoring of investor faith in the former Zaire was one of the main concerns of the new government.
Mututulo said Kabila's government intended to re-negotiate the $5 billion debt inherited from former president Mobutu Sese Seko.
Mututulo -- who said his speech was one of the first by a member of Kabila's government to an international audience -- said the country's economy needed immediate action.
"The present situation is alarming and requires drastic surgery to save the patient," he added.
The objective of Kabila's government was to create a prosperous mining industry which would assist the country's economic recovery.
Mututulo said the new Congo required large chunks of new investment and needed foreign partners.
"At this most critical time when the Congo has finally been liberated...it illustrates our efforts and the need for a massive injection of investment.
"We need new investments to rehabilitate, modernise and revitalise our economic sectors," he said.
